text: ਪ੍ਰਹਲਾਦ ਪਠਾਏ ਪੜਨ ਸਾਲ ॥
section: Basant - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Prahlaad was sent to school.

transliteration.text: prahalād pathāē paran sāl .

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. This Raag encourages the mind to brush away its selfishness, just like spring-cleaning removes all the cobwebs and creates a fresh start. There are feelings of hope and expectation of a new beginning and the start of a new cycle. However, these emotions are not dependent on the physical change of the season, but are an encouragement of an internal effort to change.

author.author: Saint Kabir
author.description:
Saint Kabir [1440 - 1518] was a Muslim mystic born in Varanasi in India, whose 541 hymns are included in the Guru Granth Sahib. His writings about God are full of love and devotion, very direct and striking in appeal.

The birth of Kabir remains to this day shrouded in mystery and legend. Authorities disagree on both when he was born and who his parents were. One legend proclaims a divine virginal birth. His mother was reputed to have been of the Brahman caste and to have become pregnant after a visit to a Hindu shrine.

Because she was unwed, she abandoned Kabir, who was found and adopted by a Muslim weaver. That his early life began as a Muslim there is no doubt, although he later became influenced by the Hindu ascetic, Ramananda, who he accepted as his Guru.

text: ਸੰਗਿ ਸਖਾ ਬਹੁ ਲੀਏ ਬਾਲ ॥
section: Basant - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: He took many of his friends along with him.

transliteration.text: sang sakhā bah līē bāl .

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. This Raag encourages the mind to brush away its selfishness, just like spring-cleaning removes all the cobwebs and creates a fresh start. There are feelings of hope and expectation of a new beginning and the start of a new cycle. However, these emotions are not dependent on the physical change of the season, but are an encouragement of an internal effort to change.

author.author: Saint Kabir
author.description:

Because she was unwed, she abandoned Kabir, who was found and adopted by a Muslim weaver. That his early life began as a Muslim there is no doubt, although he later became influenced by the Hindu ascetic, Ramananda, who he accepted as his Guru.

text: ਮੋ ਕਉ ਕਹਾ ਪੜ੍ਹਾਵਸਿ ਆਲ ਜਾਲ ॥
section: Basant - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: He asked his teacher, "Why do you teach me about worldly affairs?

transliteration.text: mō kau kahā parhāvas āl jāl .

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. This Raag encourages the mind to brush away its selfishness, just like spring-cleaning removes all the cobwebs and creates a fresh start. There are feelings of hope and expectation of a new beginning and the start of a new cycle. However, these emotions are not dependent on the physical change of the season, but are an encouragement of an internal effort to change.

author.description:

text: ਮੇਰੀ ਪਟੀਆ ਲਿਖਿ ਦੇਹੁ ਸ੍ਰੀ ਗੋੁਪਾਲ ॥੧॥
section: Basant - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Write the Name of the Dear Lord on my tablet."||1||

transliteration.text: mērī patīā likh dēh srī gōpāl .1.

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. This Raag encourages the mind to brush away its selfishness, just like spring-cleaning removes all the cobwebs and creates a fresh start. However, these emotions are not dependent on the physical change of the season, but are an encouragement of an internal effort to change.

text: ਨਹੀ ਛੋਡਉ ਰੇ ਬਾਬਾ ਰਾਮ ਨਾਮ ॥
section: Basant - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: O Baba, I will not forsake the Name of the Lord.

transliteration.text: nahī shōdau rē bābā rām nām .

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. This Raag encourages the mind to brush away its selfishness, just like spring-cleaning removes all the cobwebs and creates a fresh start. There are feelings of hope and expectation of a new beginning and the start of a new cycle. However, these emotions are not dependent on the physical change of the season, but are an encouragement of an internal effort to change.

text: ਮੇਰੋ ਅਉਰ ਪੜ੍ਹਨ ਸਿਉ ਨਹੀ ਕਾਮੁ ॥੧॥ ਰਹਾਉ ॥
section: Basant - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: I will not bother with any other lessons. ||1||Pause||

transliteration.text: mērō aur parhan siu nahī kām .1. rahāu .

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. This Raag encourages the mind to brush away its selfishness, just like spring-cleaning removes all the cobwebs and creates a fresh start. There are feelings of hope and expectation of a new beginning and the start of a new cycle. However, these emotions are not dependent on the physical change of the season, but are an encouragement of an internal effort to change.

text: ਸੰਡੈ ਮਰਕੈ ਕਹਿਓ ਜਾਇ ॥
section: Basant - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Sanda and Marka went to the king to complain.

transliteration.text: sandai marakai kahiō jāi .

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. This Raag encourages the mind to brush away its selfishness, just like spring-cleaning removes all the cobwebs and creates a fresh start. text: ਪ੍ਰਹਲਾਦ ਬੁਲਾਏ ਬੇਗਿ ਧਾਇ ॥
section: Basant - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: He sent for Prahlaad to come at once.

transliteration.text: prahalād bulāē bēg dhāi .

section: Basant - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: He said to him, "Stop uttering the Lord's Name.

transliteration.text: tū rām kahan kī shōd bān .

section: Basant - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: I shall release you at once, if you obey my words."||2||

transliteration.text: tujh turat shadāū mērō kahiō mān .2.

section: Basant - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Prahlaad answered, "Why do you annoy me, over and over again?

transliteration.text: mō kau kahā satāvah bār bār .

text: ਪ੍ਰਭਿ ਜਲ ਥਲ ਗਿਰਿ ਕੀਏ ਪਹਾਰ ॥
section: Basant - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: God created the water, land, hills and mountains.

transliteration.text: prabh jal thal gir kīē pahār .

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. This Raag encourages the mind to brush away its selfishness, just like spring-cleaning removes all the cobwebs and creates a fresh start. text: ਇਕੁ ਰਾਮੁ ਨ ਛੋਡਉ ਗੁਰਹਿ ਗਾਰਿ ॥
section: Basant - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: I shall not forsake the One Lord; if I did, I would be going against my Guru.

transliteration.text: ik rām n shōdau gurah gār .

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. This Raag encourages the mind to brush away its selfishness, just like spring-cleaning removes all the cobwebs and creates a fresh start. There are feelings of hope and expectation of a new beginning and the start of a new cycle. However, these emotions are not dependent on the physical change of the season, but are an encouragement of an internal effort to change.

text: ਮੋ ਕਉ ਘਾਲਿ ਜਾਰਿ ਭਾਵੈ ਮਾਰਿ ਡਾਰਿ ॥੩॥
section: Basant - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: You might as well throw me into the fire and kill me."||3||

transliteration.text: mō kau ghāl jār bhāvai mār dār .3.

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. section: Basant - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: The king became angry and drew his sword.

transliteration.text: kādh kharag kōpiō risāi .

text: ਤੁਝ ਰਾਖਨਹਾਰੋ ਮੋਹਿ ਬਤਾਇ ॥
section: Basant - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Show me your protector now!

transliteration.text: tujh rākhanahārō mōh batāi .

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. This Raag encourages the mind to brush away its selfishness, just like spring-cleaning removes all the cobwebs and creates a fresh start. section: Basant - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: So God emerged out of the pillar, and assumed a mighty form.

transliteration.text: prabh thanbh tē nikasē kai bisathār .

section: Basant - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: He killed Harnaakhash, tearing him apart with his nails. ||4||

transliteration.text: haranākhas shēdiō nakh bidār .4.

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. section: Basant - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: The Supreme Lord God, the Divinity of the divine,

transliteration.text: ōi param purakh dēvādh dēv .

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. This Raag encourages the mind to brush away its selfishness, just like spring-cleaning removes all the cobwebs and creates a fresh start. text: ਭਗਤਿ ਹੇਤਿ ਨਰਸਿੰਘ ਭੇਵ ॥
section: Basant - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: for the sake of His devotee, assumed the form of the man-lion.

transliteration.text: bhagat hēt narasingh bhēv .

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. This Raag encourages the mind to brush away its selfishness, just like spring-cleaning removes all the cobwebs and creates a fresh start. There are feelings of hope and expectation of a new beginning and the start of a new cycle. However, these emotions are not dependent on the physical change of the season, but are an encouragement of an internal effort to change.

author.author: Saint Kabir
author.description:
Saint Kabir [1440 - 1518] was a Muslim mystic born in Varanasi in India, whose 541 hymns are included in the Guru Granth Sahib. His writings about God are full of love and devotion, very direct and striking in appeal.

The birth of Kabir remains to this day shrouded in mystery and legend. Authorities disagree on both when he was born and who his parents were. One legend proclaims a divine virginal birth. His mother was reputed to have been of the Brahman caste and to have become pregnant after a visit to a Hindu shrine.

Because she was unwed, she abandoned Kabir, who was found and adopted by a Muslim weaver. That his early life began as a Muslim there is no doubt, although he later became influenced by the Hindu ascetic, Ramananda, who he accepted as his Guru.

text: ਕਹਿ ਕਬੀਰ ਕੋ ਲਖੈ ਨ ਪਾਰ ॥
section: Basant - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Says Kabeer, no one can know the Lord's limits.

transliteration.text: kah kabīr kō lakhai n pār .

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. This Raag encourages the mind to brush away its selfishness, just like spring-cleaning removes all the cobwebs and creates a fresh start. There are feelings of hope and expectation of a new beginning and the start of a new cycle. However, these emotions are not dependent on the physical change of the season, but are an encouragement of an internal effort to change.

text: ਪ੍ਰਹਲਾਦ ਉਧਾਰੇ ਅਨਿਕ ਬਾਰ ॥੫॥੪॥
section: Basant - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: He saves His devotees like Prahlaad over and over again. ||5||4||

transliteration.text: prahalād udhārē anik bār .5.4.

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. This Raag encourages the mind to brush away its selfishness, just like spring-cleaning removes all the cobwebs and creates a fresh start. There are feelings of hope and expectation of a new beginning and the start of a new cycle. However, these emotions are not dependent on the physical change of the season, but are an encouragement of an internal effort to change.
